bestBHT.bht: On their way to Emmaus, about seven and a half miles from Jerusalem, two disciples engaged in a conversation about Jesus. While one of the disciples was identified as Cleopas, the other person remains a subject of conjecture. Discouraged and unable to comprehend the recent events, they arrived at the conclusion that Jesus was not the Messiah. Despite the insignificance of Emmaus, its mention adds certainty to the narrative. This Emmaus was approximately seven miles away from Jerusalem, and the disciples reached it by early evening.

Henry Alford: Who the other was, is idle to conjecture.
This may show what such reports are worth.
Our narrative seems to have been from the report of Cleopas.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: One was Cleopas (Luke 24:18); who the other was is mere conjecture.
Emmaus—about seven and a half miles from Jerusalem.
They probably lived there and were going home after the Passover.
Albert Barnes: There is no evidence to guide us here.
Certain it is that in these later ages the occupants of this place have controlled the whole adjacent region, and for many a generation exercised their lawless tyranny upon helpless pilgrims.

They seem to have given up all for lost, and to have come to the conclusion that Jesus was not the Messiah, though they naturally conversed about it, and there were many things which they could not explain.
John Calvin: it is highly useful to be known and worthy of being remembered
those were two chosen witnesses, by whom the Lord intended, not to convince the apostles that he was risen, but to reprove their slowness
Luke... named [Emmaus], not so much on account of its celebrity, as to add certainty to the narrative.
Philip Schaff: The name seems to be == Cleopatrus (as Antipas == Antipatros), and a different one from Clopas (or ‘Cleophas’ in the E. V.) mentioned in John 19:25.
Opinion is divided between two places, now called respectively Kubeibeh and Kulonich, both west of Jerusalem (the latter more to the north).
Sixty furlongs (stadia) = about eight English miles. They therefore probably left Jerusalem early in the afternoon, thus reaching Emmaus about sundown.
Archibald T. Robertson: Were going (ησαν πορευομενο). Periphrastic imperfect middle of πορευομα.
Sixty stadia (σταδιους εξηκοντα). About seven miles.
John Gill: On the 'same day'; the first day of the week; the day on which Christ rose from the dead; and the third day from his death it was.
The place whither they went is particularly mentioned, not because it was a place of note, but for the certainty of the fact.
Another Emmaus is here meant: which was from Jerusalem about threescore furlongs; or seven miles and a half.

bhtAttempts.bht: Two disciples were on their way to Emmaus, about seven and a half miles from Jerusalem. It is unclear who the second disciple was, but it is believed that the account was based on the report of Cleopas. They were conversing about Jesus, trying to make sense of the events that had occurred. Feeling disillusioned, they had lost hope and concluded that Jesus was not the Messiah. They left Jerusalem early in the afternoon, arriving in Emmaus around sundown. This particular Emmaus is mentioned to add certainty to the narrative, despite it not being a significant place.

Despite the insignificance of Emmaus, its mention adds certainty to the narrative. This Emmaus was approximately seven miles away from Jerusalem, and the disciples reached it by early evening.

Despite the insignificance of Emmaus, its mention adds certainty to the narrative.

They were conversing about Jesus, trying to make sense of the events that had occurred. Feeling disillusioned, they had lost hope and concluded that Jesus was not the Messiah. They left Jerusalem early in the afternoon, arriving in Emmaus around sundown. This particular Emmaus is mentioned to add certainty to the narrative, despite it not being a significant place.

On their way to Emmaus, about seven and a half miles from Jerusalem, two disciples engaged in a conversation about Jesus. While one of the disciples was identified as Cleopas, the other remains unknown, leaving room for conjecture. Frustrated and unable to grasp the recent events, they reached the conclusion that Jesus was not the Messiah. They departed Jerusalem in the afternoon, arriving at Emmaus by sundown. The mention of this specific Emmaus adds credibility to the account, despite its lack of prominence.
